content.raw: There are states classes for the left team and for the right team, e.g.: `CornerKickLeftState` and `CornerKickRightState`. Most of the code is the same between them, except a few lines. Consider to refactor this as a single class `CornerKickState` that accepts a parameter in the constructor that tells you which team you are.
content.html: There are states classes for the left team and for the right team, e.g.: CornerKickLeftState and CornerKickRightState. Most of the code is the same between them, except a few lines. Consider to refactor this as a single class CornerKickState that accepts a parameter in the constructor that tells you which team you are.

content.raw: I will think about this. One potential concern is that in the future there might be some asymmetrical rules where the play mode transitions for the team on the left side differs from the right side.
content.html: I will think about this. One potential concern is that in the future there might be some asymmetrical rules where the play mode transitions for the team on the left side differs from the right side.

content.raw: If that's the case you can always create two separate classes when needed but it looks to me that right now all the left/right states have the same code except one line. This can produce copy/paste errors and it will make the code harder to maintain because you'll have to remember to modify the code in the two different classes.
content.html: If that's the case you can always create two separate classes when needed but it looks to me that right now all the left/right states have the same code except one line. This can produce copy/paste errors and it will make the code harder to maintain because you'll have to remember to modify the code in the two different classes.

content.raw:
I think it's fine to leave it here for now, but generally we prefer to only add variables on the same pull request as their usage is introduced. That way it makes more sense for the people reviewing it. Right now, just looking at this variable, I don't know what to conclude - maybe the whole camera pose is needed, or the logic will change and this won't be needed anymore (and we would probably end up with a useless variable because by then we will forget this was here...).

Just a pointer to try and make compact pull requests which are self-contained :wink:
content.html:
I think it's fine to leave it here for now, but generally we prefer to only add variables on the same pull request as their usage is introduced. That way it makes more sense for the people reviewing it. Right now, just looking at this variable, I don't know what to conclude - maybe the whole camera pose is needed, or the logic will change and this won't be needed anymore (and we would probably end up with a useless variable because by then we will forget this was here...).

Just a pointer to try and make compact pull requests which are self-contained
